At this point, we can safely assume that our dominance over Italy is only a matter of time. Even so, we should continue to expand - our minds focused always on the task at hand.

We've learned a lot from them. In our infancy, we learned civilisation from their example and their strength deterred the others' ambitions against us. Unfortunately, when the time came, they failed to recognise us as peers; now, they shall accept us as superiors!

The quality and variety of entertainment in a society is proof of its greatness and eminence. We are fighters, competitors and athletes - our blood is hot and our celebrations passionate. Just come to the circus and it all will make sense!

We have been looking at Magna Graecia, with its rolling pastures, rich soils and abundance of useful resources. Its weather, too, is favourably warm and its settlements populous. Strategically, it is in our best interest to assume control there as soon as possible.
Overseas Expansion

The Latin people are our cousins. The people of the mountains, on the other hand, are more of a pain in the neck than an itch. They both hold territories in immediate proximity to Rome. Obviously, it is in their interests to partner with us... and be a protective buffer.
A Kingdom of Myth & Legend
From Distant Lands

Our horizons widen. To the south lie territories with fertile lands and rich coastal waters; to the north, barbarians roam the hills. It seems that we face two different priorities of equal intensity. The simplest course of action is to conquer them both!
Controlling the World

It has been ten years since military hostilities began between us and the Etruscan city of Veii. Situated very close to each other, we have been rivals for more than a century. We cannot share power and influence with these people anymore. Only one can prevail.

For the Emperor!
The conflict with the greedy Seleucids was inevitable. Soon, Nabataea marched to war against a much larger and stronger enemy.
Nabataea needed to institute firm control over the Arabian tribes so its focus could be turned towards much greater deeds.
The Nabataeans were skilled engineers, who were always looking for innovation in construction techniques.
With many lands now under its rule and trade routes under its control, the kingdom of Nabataea held a monopoly over the import and export of many valuable goods.
The east is vast and powerful, but home to many powerful rivals. In this climate, the Nabateans needed to secure their lands in order to prosper.
Fighting so many Greek states inevitably lead to the 'Hellenisation' of the Nabataean army, improving their drill and battlefield tactics, which made them even stronger.
The Greeks were always considered to be masters of warfare; the Nabateans were wise to adopt their fighting styles and prowess.
Trade was one of the founding pillars of Nabataean wealth. As such, their trade routes stretched to the far corners of the world.
Nabataean engineers continued to innovate and establish advanced construction techniques and practices.
Jerusalem has always been strategically vital to all the surrounding kingdoms; control of the city would play a critical role in the wars to come.
Nabataea also had to secure the region's important naval trade routes, and for that a mighty fleet was needed.
The once proud kingdom of the Seleucids would be brought to its knees, in what would be one of the greatest victories in Nabataean history.
Although Egypt had always been a land of myth and legend, it also held vast riches and an abundance of produce; it was time for Nabataea to take the kingdom from its current rulers.
As Nabataea grew increasingly formidable, the need for a well-established economy became a top priority.
After long and exhausting wars, the Greek states were finally brought to their knees and put firmly under Nabataean control.
The Nabateans never stopped trying to extend their borders further and further into the known world. Often, these attempts were successful.
With their astonishing mastery of stonemasonry, the Nabateans managed to build one of the greatest cities, which would remain a landmark in the region for many years to come.
Even the greatest city of them all was brought under Nabataean control; truly, nothing could stand now in their way.

As the Gothi expanded, Cannabaudes faced the serious challenge of maintaining a host of sufficient strength. It was necessary to tread the path of diplomacy and persuade other German tribes to share their warriors with the Gothi.

The Legions of Emperor Aurelian were still under his command. Although they could not hope to topple the mighty reiksdom of the Gothi, Cannabaudes knew that the best Roman Emperor is a subdued Roman Emperor.
Long were the arms of Cannabaudes. They easily reached the Zenobia's last strongholds and toppled the independent queen from her throne.
Tetricus, the one-time Gallic Roman Emperor, was still clinging to his Imperial ambitions. Cannabaudes marched against the him, to put an end to his ambition and perhaps even his life.
The Gothi were impatient warriors and the walls of Zarmizegetusa appeared daunting to many of them. Cannabaudes knew that some easy loot would feed their courage.
Rich lands dotted the eastern shore of Pontus Euxinus as well. They seemed poorly defended against seaborne raids but in order to conduct these, Cannabaudes needed a proper port nearby.
The Gothi had been using a writing system and Cannabaudes issued a law ordering its use. He needed a way, it is said, for his deeds to be recorded and thus remain in history.
Rhodos was not spared the wrath of marauding Gothic fleets. It is said that even Cannabaudes himself was aghast when he learned of the city's final fate.
Cannabaudes had heard of Armenia and its honourable warriors. They seemed a worthy foe and a wealthy one too.
Constant looting brought heaps of gold to Cannabaudes. Still, it was evident to him that his marauding parties could be much more efficient if a certain level of organisation was introduced.
The city of Massilia was a major trade centre for the Mare Internum. The Gothi recognised its importance and proceeded to claim the treasures within the city walls for themselves.
Gothic lust for loot did not spare Gallic lands. They descended upon Bibracte like birds of prey and reduced the city to a sorry ruin.
The Gothi had achieved a greatness and power that almost eclipsed the great Roman Empire. The reign of king Cannabaudes will be remembered as long as men walk the earth.
The Buri, to the north of Gothic lands, had been an old friend to Cannabaudes and his people. Surely they would be happy to join forces with the Gothi\?

The nomadic people of the Heruli controlled the steppes to the east of the Gothi. It is said that Reiks Cannabaudes ordered the attack against them after being personally insulted by a band of travelling Heruli.
The fortified city of Nicomedia stood on the border between Thracia and Bithynia Et Pontus. The Gothi moved to take it and thus secure a foothold for further southern conquest.
The Gothi sailed on their small boats across the Mare Aegaeum. They landed near Gortyna and proceeded to thoroughly pillage the unsuspecting town.
The Gothi had a long lasting feud with the Alani. It seemed that of all Gothic leaders, Cannabaudes was the one that would avenge his people by subduing the insolent nomads.
The Armenians indeed fought well and Cannabaudes treated them with respect, even as he ground their forces into dust.
Cannabaudes wisely chose to mint coins bearing his image. In this way his rule was legitimised; his subjects would behold his face every day.

After his great many victories, it is said that Cannabaudes received visits from Germanic chiefs almost every day. Each one pledged his allegiance to the Gothi, yet the reiks accepted only a few; even in victory he was a cautious ruler.

The Gothi were said to have come from the far north, led by Gaut, their ancient chief and father of their people. King Cannabaudes built many sacred shrines dedicated to his ancestor in the hope of his divine favour.
The victories of Cannabaudes attracted many warriors eager to prove their worth before the white-haired reiks.

We followed our chieftain across the Alps in search for our new home. We settled here, in Senonia, on the Mediterranean coast. The land is fine, but sadly far from secure - our survival now depends on access to more land and resources.

Our most powerful rivals occupy the lands to the west and the south. Before we can engage them, however, our druids point to the north, where our neighbours are weakly defended; these are lands which the gods have decreed will be ours.

Rumour has it that a messenger from a distant land visited Brennus recently, presenting a lucrative opportunity. Shortly afterwards, Brennus announced his decision to attack the city of Taras. Whatever the reason, we will draw Greek blood this day, and gorge ourselves on plunder.

With the success of our armies, Brennus' glory encompasses all. To honour him, we must improve our understanding of construction techniques, ensuring we our buildings achieve a new level of majesty. The world, in return, will be more agreeable...

Some say that Dionysius, the tyrant of Syracuse, recruited Brennus. Maybe, who can say for sure\? On the other hand, Rome is the ultimate prize - a cocky republic with an overblown sense of grandeur. Do we really need more reasons to teach these upstarts a lesson\?

Carthage is a jewel of a city, the capital of a powerful empire and the possessor of great treasures. To raze such a giant would bring us not just riches, but glory also. There are also many in the wider world who will appreciate Carthage's downfall.

The Tarentine people are sophisticated and proud. They have a glorious past and will not accept an inglorious present. However, we cannot afford this ever-growing resentment to our rule in our heartlands. Unfortunately, they must go.
Many of the steppe nomads respected the Alani for keeping up the ancient ways of the horse people. As a result, some of the tribes desired Alani friendship and could be loyal allies.
Among the Alani there were always people prone to exchanging goods with foreigners rather than prising them from their cold, dead fingers.
In older times, the Gothi had driven Alani to the east of Sarmatian lands. Now they had returned, they carried the fire of revenge on their spears and in their hearts.
The Armenians were worthy opponents. Archers of unsurpassed skill and riders of formidable renown, they fought well before finally succumbing to Alani might.
The Taifali were a nomadic people famous for their skilled mounted warriors. Although they were allies of the Gothi, the Alani aimed to recruit them to their side.

The Alani did not flinch at the sight of Palmyra's walls. They captured them and then their horsemen entered the city. Nothing was spared; palaces, temples and homes all burnt after being completely robbed.
During their great eastern expansion, the Alani remained true to their marauding ways and sacked every town and village, whether their occupants resisted or not.
The Sassanid Shahanshah, Hormizd, had suffered the Alani's blows with resolution. Yet the steppe lords were determined to bring him, and the entire Sassanid dynasty, down.
Emperor Aurelian was a strong man, a born leader, one of the few who could still threaten the Alani if he could muster sufficient troops. He had to be dealt with before he managed to do so.
More and more horsemen arrived each day at the Alani royal camp. Boastful tales of heroic past deeds were told before the Alani king and pompous oaths of allegiance were made.

The nomads came riding on swift horses, wielding deceptively small bows, their screams sending chills into the very bones of ordinary folk. After trophies and riches were collected and securely tied to the saddle, the raiders vanished again into the night.
The endless steppe was home to many mounted warriors. Their combined strength was immeasurable yet they would obey only the call of a truly outstanding chief.
Tales of Armenian riches reached the Alani and they declared war with no fear in their hearts, for how could a free horse master fear those who cowered behind the walls of a city\?
The Alani required their warriors to train daily with the bow. Archery contests were often held to determine the personal skill of each entrant.
The Scythian chieftains of old often turned to the enaree shamans for divine advice and direction. Many years later, the Alani restored the mystic order to benefit from their unearthly knowledge.

It is said that the Sassanids expected the attack on Ctesiphon. Their forces gave battle but quickly wavered and fled. The capital city was bereft of defenders and soon it was bereft of valuables too!
Having fought against Sassanid cataphracts, the Alani saw merit in fielding greater numbers of heavily-armoured horses in battle.
In the great deserts of the world, semi-nomadic kingdoms held sway. The Alani horses did not fear the heat and neither did their riders, especially when there was loot to be had.

The most distinguished of the Alani chiefs and warriors received tombs of appropriate splendour. In this way, the benevolence of their spirits was assured and they would aid the tribe from the Otherworld.

Masters of the World
To Rome!

Palmyrene forces advanced towards Rome, overcoming any resistance they came across. With the Eternal City within her grasp, Zenobia made the political arrangements necessary for acceptance by the Senate.
It was an old dream of Zenobia to control the Greek shores of Mare Aegaeum. To that end, she outfitted another expedition, which brought her into direct conflict with Emperor Aurelian once again.
Then, Zenobia turned her ambitious gaze to the western shores of Mare Internum. Roman forces there were ready for an invasion but the queen hoped that diplomacy would suffice.
Palmyra's Legions surged north, deep into Gaul. With every major city in the area threatened, Tetricus' army had little chance of overcoming the invaders.

After assuming power, Zenobia's armies converged in the west, in the fertile lands around the Nile. Not only was Aegyptos a rich province in its own right, but the grain it produced fed the great city of Rome itself.
Zenobia's next move was to establish a foothold in Asia Minor to facilitate her further expansion. Unfortunately, the entire peninsula was held by forces loyal to Emperor Aurelian.

The province of Africa belonged to Emperor Aurelian, yet it was separated from the rest of his lands by sea. Zenobia moved to conquer it, even capturing the Sicilian city of Agrigentum. Thus the preparations for taking Rome itself were complete.
Despite attempts to maintain peace with the eastern empires, once her struggle with the Roman Emperors was at an end, Zenobia directed her armies towards Persia. As you might expect, war soon ensued.
Philosophy and natural sciences flourished in the Palmyrene Empire. Laws were established and their justice absolute; trade and crafts were practiced and improved. A golden era was coming.

What goes around, comes around - as someone may have once said. We have begun our ascent by curbing the ambitions of Carthage in Sardinia. Now, we are in position to establish our place in history by sending Carthage into its annals, defeated!

We have become quite efficient at showing up unexpectedly at the coastal cities of eastern Italy! This tactic keeps our warriors, as well as our rivals, on their toes. Just beyond the horizon, to the east, lies Latium, and to the south, Carthage. To arms!

New lands lie before us, fertile and favourable in terrain. Gaining control over easily accessible valleys and fields in northern Italy and Sicily promises to be highly beneficial. With our military prowess, it also seems easily achievable.

With the expansion of our territories we are starting to encounter tribes and cities with different cultures and strange deities. Some of them are powerful and possessive, so it is of great importance that we keep our own traditions alive and strong.

Our roots are strong yet insular. The natural limits of our territory hinder growth and expansion, so an established stronghold on the mainland would provide our kin with space for further development. The lands to the north seem most suitable!

The Balearic island of Corsica lies in our backyard. Its resources are dismissively small but its importance for our safety is paramount. Establishing control over the island will shield us against aggression from the north, and could also be a stepping stone for future expansion.

Sardinia is our home, generous in food and water. Her forests provide wood and shelter, her coasts, wealth and safety. However, Sardinia, unfortunately, is not ours. Carthage controls some of her territory - it is most urgent that we change that situation!

Only a handful of the very bravest among his troops were accepted into Aurelian's Herculianii units.

In addition to the regular, official grain supply, Emperor Aurelian managed to arrange further Egyptian food transports. The bulky ships regularly sailed from Alexandria towards Roman ports around the Mediterranean.
In his wars, Emperor Aurelian came to appreciate the usefulness of smaller troop detachments that could quickly deal with problems and thus prevent them from escalating into major crises.
The memory of Emperor Valerian's cruel demise at Sassanid hands fuelled Aurelian's anger. Although he had only just triumphed over Palmyra and Gaul, he prepared to march on another foe.
The city of Mediolanum was of paramount strategic importance. It was well defended and could serve as a base of operations during the inevitable war with Gallic Rome.
Emperor Aurelian was not a simple soldier. Along with his military stratagems, he reformed laws and regulations with a general's methodical approach.
Sooner or later, swords had to be drawn. Aurelian had neither the patience nor the desire to negotiate with Zenobia, he was intent on subduing her by way of force.

As the Roman Empire weathered the crisis, Emperor after Emperor had been reducing the quantity of silver in the antoninianii in a desperate attempt to keep their purses full. Aurelian was first to begin nourishing the Imperial coffers back to health.

The cavalry might of the eastern empires could only be countered by cavalry of similar magnitude and sophistication. Thus Aurelian outfitted several regiments of equites cataphractarii - heavily armoured horsemen.
Zenobia still posed a threat as long as there was a scrap of land under her control. Therefore, Emperor Aurelian set out to remove every last vestige of her presence.
Along with Lusitania, Hispania had to be conquered for Rome's Iberian provinces to be restored under the rightful rule of 'Aurelian the Invincible'.
To secure the well-being of the Empire, wise Aurelian relied on the stout shields of the Jovianii.

The Sassanids had conquered Armenia and installed a member of their own dynasty on the throne. Now, as Aurelian advanced eastwards, he intended to return the kingdom to its rightful rulers... under the wings of the Roman eagle!
The Germanic raids into Roman lands had been growing in boldness by the day. Aurelian chose to retaliate against the Quadi in order to secure his northern border as he marched west.
Quintillus' forces had to be eradicated. Thus, not only did Aurelian lose an enemy, but he also showed any other potential foes what fate awaited them.
During Aurelian's reign, no other deity received greater honours than Sol Invictus. The Emperor himself urged all Romans to spare no expense when sacrificing to the god.

The indomitable Aurelian did not let the desire to defeat Palmyra blind him to other dangers. He realised he needed to keep Dacia and Galatia et Cappadocia under his rule to secure the safety of his passage over land.
Palmyra had many allies amongst the denizens of the desert. Aurelian decided that a show of force would dissuade these allies from making a stand against him.
The grain coming from Aegyptos was of vital importance to the city of Rome. Aurelian needed to retain the vast farmland in his influence either directly or by relying on a loyal governor.
Lusitania's governors had always claimed they resented living in Tetricus' shadow. Yet, as the demise of Gallic Rome approached, Lusitanian generals suddenly opposed Aurelian. They had to be subdued.
Even though Aurelian controlled most of Gaul, he had to make sure that not a single occupant opposed his rule.
Aurelian was almost always unforgiving towards his enemies. As eastern settlements were reduced to smouldering ruins, their willingness to resist the Roman onslaught rapidly diminished.
Dionysius was once a neighbour. Lately, his ambitions seem to clash with our own. The future of Taras demands we either conquer his lands or bend the knee before him, which is hardly a choice at all!
Taras is both wealthy and prosperous. In his wisdom, Archytas sees that our growing influence can hardly be contained within our current territories. The natural way forward points north.
It is time to take what rightfully belongs to us - southern Italy can have many inhabitants, but only one master!
The prosperity of our people and the success of our armies requires observance of the correct votive offerings and rites. It also demands that our architecture reflects our standing in the world.
Southern Italy lies before us, rich in resources and fertile in population. She is ready to welcome us as her new masters. No other nation can match our power, nor has divine permission to do so.
Holding Magna Graecia in her entirety is paramount. Archytas made that clear very early on in his reign and we are happy to follow his vision - a vision that will lead us well beyond the horizon.

Times are promising; the lands of southern Italy are fertile, and the weather is most favourable for our needs. Our home, both beautiful and comfortable, must be preserved. To do this we must establish a strong backbone by securing the coastal lands nearby.

The forests of Sardinia are generous, supplying us with food, wood and clothing. We have to profess our gratitude and respect to the gods - it is due to their blessings that we enjoy this abundance of game and edible plants.

The Carthaginians have been bothering us for decades, causing annoyance and genuine hardship for many of our people. Fortunately, we have the time sensibly and learned all about Carthage and its ways. Now, we will easily prevail against them on the field of battle!

Even though we are self-sufficient when it comes to food, clothes and shelter, there are some items we cannot produce alone, and for them we rely on trade. Establishing mercantile partnerships requires a good reputation and trust between the parties, which is not always easy to achieve.

Tarchuna is a powerful and wealthy city. Its naval ambitions are focused on the seas surrounding Sardinia, which has naturally brought it into conflict with the Greeks and Carthaginians. In spite of this, partnering with Tarchuna may prove profitable for us if we play the game cleverly...

Brennus has earned a reputation as a fearsome warrior and formidable foe. It is too bad that his reputation is a useless weapon against us. Capturing his home territories will rightfully reduce him to an insignificant barbarian chieftain with a very loud mouth!

We are hard people who lead a hard life. We know that all our gains come through work, bravery and respectful worship of the gods. We celebrate our achievements with great feasts, to clearly display our appreciation and gratitude to the powers responsible.
Success rests on the acquisition of sufficient resources and their wise and prudent use. Securing essential resources is always a prudent measure, one that promises stability and peace for all.
Whatever we gain, we gain through hard work and commitment. The fruits of our labour are, therefore, valuable and should be preserved; well-constructed storage buildings will serve that function.
The Iolei people are nothing without their roots, planted by the father of the tribe: the divine Sardus. When we honour Sardus, we nurture not just our people's prosperity, but their destiny also.

The backbone of our army are its strong and powerful javelinmen. If we are to have a lasting legacy, we must ensure that we field an unbeatable force. The recruitment of half a dozen well-trained units is a reasonable first step towards achieving this.

We are islanders. Most of our food supplies therefore come from the sea, which is a generous patron and a trusted friend. At our current rate of growth, we will need to harvest more, so must construct larger ports.

Our territories grow, and along with them, the number of people under our control. Our adversaries grow desperate and more aggressive. To maintain and solidify our position, we must ensure the battlefield strength of our archers is second to none.

Sardinia's forests are rich and bountiful, and we have experienced craftsmen who can work the wood with great skill. In their workshops they prepare weapons and arrows, as well as furniture and other household items. As such, we should build more and better production facilities.
The only thing stronger than well-trained, experienced army is a much larger, more experienced and better-trained force.
The war cost Armenia dearly, so its authorities focused on collecting taxes with meticulous punctuality. Soon enough, gleaming gold was neatly piled into the treasury.
Armenia had strong armies and sufficient wealth to fund its further expansion to the west and south. Once this expansion was completed, the old days of Great Armenia would draw nigh!
In order to prove themselves worthy allies to the Sassanids, the Armenians pursued aggressive expansion. The war against Lydia only helped their interests.
Aegyptos had seemed distant, a land that only merchants had spoken of. Yet, now the rich fields around the Nile were within Armenia's grasp, its noble generals did not hesitate to capture them.
Then Armenians expanded across the islands of Mare Internum and Libya. Soon enough, a massive maritime empire sprawled from Africa to Achaia.

Armenian power and prominence grew and soon the time came to expand northwards. This time, its war aims were the capture of new lands and to cripple the steppe raiders who, time and again, sent raiding parties against peaceful Armenian settlements.

The rich lands of Syria and Judea appeared to be the next logical step along the glorious road of Armenian expansion. These lands enjoyed access to the trading lanes of the Mare Internum, and were thus a profitable asset.
A swift strike across core Sassanid lands was sure to bring their empire to its knees. A bold and ambitious undertaking, this plan was bound to bear the sweet fruit of victory.
In its heyday, the new 'Grand Armenia' established an intricate system of trade routes, via which goods and gold flowed straight towards its capital.

Our achievements are many. Well versed are we in the ways of fine living and elegant dying. Our neighbours and rivals are easily attracted to what we can offer them.
We control ever-larger pieces of land, something which requires further interpretation of the sacred texts - our people's growth is intrinsically linked to our knowledge of the divine.

Insubria is of high strategic value to those wishing to secure their northern borders and protect them from attack. Its people, unfortunately, claim an ancient right of ownership over this territory and show no interest in a mutually-beneficial solution. We have no choice but to remove them.

They buy our pottery, hire our mural-painters and drink our wine. They practice our rituals and enjoy the same entertainment. They imitate our leisure and our labour. They are the people of Italy, the Etruscans to be.

Etruria is a fine and precious land, one that allows our people to prosper in accordance with the gods' will. Our culture and wealth are unsurpassed, our rivals inferior. The neighbouring territories should naturally fall under our control.

At first, they showed some potential. Then, they bet their future on their great 'republic' - a civilised society like no other. However, the spark that brought Rome into existence will never turn into a raging, uncontrollable fire.

Tarchuna, the shining city on the hill, attracts the gaze of envious eyes, both from within Italy and from beyond its borders. To protect our home and prosperity, it would be wise to establish a buffer between us and our neighbours. Acquiring a few new territories should suffice.

Into Warmer Waters
The Power & The Glory

Keep your oaths and the gods will reward you - it is not a surprise, therefore, that we have grown and prospered. It is time to show our respect to the divine order which nurtures our kin, for all to see.

The north is still untamed - dangers of different kinds lurk in the shadows. Romans, Senones and Etruscans are looking at our growing power with alarm and disdain. Facing them in battle will be unavoidable.

We control a significant part of Italy, which makes us one of the most influential players on the peninsula. However, strength breeds opposition and overwhelming strength crushes it. It seems that we have but one path to follow…

The Tarentine people are sophisticated and proud. They have a glorious past and will not accept an inglorious present. However, we cannot afford this ever-growing resentment to our rule in our heartlands. Unfortunately, they must go.

The mountains are our home, providing us with everything we need. The sea coast, however, offers riches far beyond our current means. To prevent the current occupants from growing too strong, it is imperative that we secure this territory for ourselves.

The fertile lands of Magna Graecia enable steady agricultural production for relatively little effort. For the hard-working high-lander, such places are a gift from the gods... a gift which must first be acquired.

The rest of Southern Italy lies before us, fertile and well populated. The only hinderance to our expansion has a Greek face. Yet the Greeks are intruders in Italy - these lands belong to our people by right.

Think About an End
The people of the Marcomanni had seen war and strife and now needed a life of appropriate luxury. The king himself saw to it, by acquiring  for his people every rare commodity that could be found.
Hold This Ground
By controlling a few key regions, Saba managed to establish a monopoly over the flow of goods passing through it.
Merely having access to the Mare Internum was not enough for the intrepid Marcomanni. Their ships sailed south and captured all major coasts around the Mare Ionium and Mare Africum.
Watching Our Backs
Through rigorous diplomacy and unprecedented military might, the Sabaean kingdom entered into legend. Tales of its exploits and achievements echo down the centuries.
The thing that generations of Romans feared finally happened: barbarians entered the Eternal City and, unlike Brennus of old, did not intend to leave.
Saba continued to take control of the regions along the shores of the Great Sea, overshadowing even the great empire of the Egyptian pharaohs of old.

A whirlwind of destruction, the Marcomanni plundered city after city. They gathered goods, gold and slaves, distributed them among themselves, and it is said that even the lowliest warriors became as rich as kings.

From humble beginnings, the Sabaean kingdom grew into one of the greatest powers in the known world. Despite their many achievements, Saba sought to leave a legacy that would be remembered for centuries to come.
The Marcomanni then proceeded to unite more Germanic tribes under their banner. However there were certain chiefs who openly opposed the idea, who were swiftly and brutally dealt with.
It would not be long before the Sabaeans established complete control over the trade in the east, making them some of the wealthiest people in the ancient world.

As the war against Rome was in full sway, all warriors young and old grew increasingly eager for loot. Many Roman settlements were stripped bare of valuables, their inhabitants enslaved, and the houses set ablaze.
Saba soon became the largest and wealthiest kingdom in the east, controlling vast swathes of territory and establishing their rule with cunning diplomacy alongside military might.

Having established a firm hold over vast territories, the Marcomanni were finally ready to march against Aurelian in earnest. Their armies entered Pannonia, their war cries ringing over the vast fields.
The ever-expanding trade routes often required protection, and it was not long before Saba had to muster large armies to see-off threats.
The Marcomanni poured out of their ancestral forest and through bold conquest quickly enlarged their domain, much to the dismay and awe of other barbarian tribes.
On the wings of many victories, the Sabaeans were filled with ambition, soon craving the riches of the vast lands to the east.

Hercynia had been home of the Marcomanni for generations. They shared the great wood with the Alemanni and Quadi, and knew that he who controlled the entire forest would in effect own an enormous impregnable fortress.
As the Sabaean kingdom grew, all of Arabia came to know and respect them.

Warriors of the Desert
Rise to Power
The time has come for us to take what is rightfully ours - Magna Graecia can have many occupants but only one master!
The prosperity of our people and the success of our armies requires better organisation at home. It also demands that our architecture reflects our standing in the world.
Raze the city, enslave the populace and enjoy the spoils. Deliver all future generations from this Punic menace!
Our dominance of the sea is fundamental to the continued prosperity of our people. Securing a stronghold in Sardinia will ensure that waves belong to us.

Times are perilous. Carthage is ambitious and has a footing in Sicily; our home is not really our own. We desperately need that to change. First, we will establish a strong backbone and secure the fertile lands at the foot of Mount Etna.
Magna Graecia lies before us, rich in resources and fertile in population. She is ready to welcome us as her new masters. No other nation can match our power, nor has divine permission to do so.
Holding Sicily in her entirety is paramount. Dionysius made that clear very early on in his reign and we are happy to follow his vision - a vision that will lead us well beyond the horizon.
Your faction has lost this region:
When knowledge is acquired it shall be written down, and so preserved. This is the way all civilised people learn and pass this learning on to the younger generation.
The presence of running water is a sign of civilisation and a people healthy and clean. Water is a gift from the gods and a nurturer of life. We celebrate and honour it!

The backbone of our army are its strong and powerful infantry. If we are to have a lasting legacy, we must ensure that we field an unbeatable force. The recruitment of half a dozen well-trained units is a reasonable first step towards achieving this.

The customs governing the consumption and storage of food are indicative of a society's level of sophistication. We strive to manufacture and use only the very best pottery; our amphorae are of very high quality due to our excellent production techniques.

As our territories expand, so too does the number of people living under our yoke. As we grow, so do our adversaries grow more desperate and more aggressive. To maintain and solidify our position, we must ensure the mobility of our armies is second to none.

A society's manner of entertainment is a measure of its sophistication. The quality and variety of artistic occupations is a proof of greatness and eminence. We are authors, playwrights, musicians and scientists; we are also philosophers and athletes... and we throw the best parties.
The only thing stronger than well-trained, experienced army is a much larger, more experienced and better-trained force.

For us, there are glorious days ahead, as spoken of by the gods, for they have blessed us with this superior breed of horses with brave and skilful riders. Tarentine cavalry is well known across Magna Graecia; soon, the rest of the world will know of it also.

Greek wine, famous across Italy, is a valuable trade good and an important feature of religious rituals. Most importantly, men feel great when consuming it. We know how to live well, and high quality wine is a major ingredient of that good living.

Taras is the largest trade centre in Magna Graecia, where our people sell a variety of goods and purchase many of their supplies. Establishing mercantile partnerships requires a good reputation and trust between the parties, which isn't easy to achieve.

Carthage is the capital of a powerful empire; one that possesses of great treasures. Befriending such a city promises vast opportunities for trade and increases our chances of military success. As Syracuse appears to be its main rival, a partnership with us must look very attractive...

At first, they showed potential - even displaying sufficient ambition to be equals with Rome, but then stuck to their narrow-minded way of living, suitable only for the mountains; clearly, they couldn't adapt to a civilised way of life. Now, they just stain the mountains with their barbarism.
Knowledge possesses a mysterious quality; the more you know, the more it seems there is to learn. It is a gift from the gods, for there will always be mysteries, adventures and secrets to uncover.
Success rests on the acquisition of sufficient resources and their wise and prudent use. Securing essential resources is always a prudent measure, one that promises stability and peace for all.

The Dahae were a nomadic people who lived on the eastern Caspian shore. They were prone to raiding Sassanid possessions to the south. The only way to put an end to these raids involved a lot of spearmen.
The capital of Zenobia's realm was filled to the brim with riches. The Sassanid Shahanshah chose to take them by force.
The kingdom of Nabataea proved troublesome for the growing Sassanid Empire. Their value as allies was dubitable but certainly less than their value as servants.
Hormizd, son of Shapur, son of Ardashir, never failed to praise the achievements of his predecessors and proudly state  that he was their worthy heir.
With his lands constantly expanding, Hormizd established many sources of income for his state and people. This prudence served him well, for the coffers of the treasury swelled.
The Shahanshah deemed Numidia and its people a fine addition to the Sassanid Empire.
It took considerable strength to defend the vast Sassanid lands. Fortunately for the Shahanshah, every man in the realm was eager to join the ranks of the royal army.

Hormizd sought out a master sculptor of unsurpassed skill and ordered him to build an enormous statue of his father. It is said that once it was completed, Hormizd was so pleased that the sculptor never had to work again…

The indomitable Sassanid armies marched west of Rome into lands unknown. It is said that when Hormizd stood on the shore of the Western ocean near Bibracte, he sipped its waters and winced. Tastes as bad""", he announced, indignantly."""
In order to accomplish his many great plans for domination, Hormizd needed to quickly expand his armies. Once he fielded sufficient troops victory was just a matter of time.
Sassanid merchants sent to foreign lands were told time and again that the Shahanshah was not avaricious - he used gold only to improve the comfort of his people.
Zenobia of Palmyra refused to wield before Hormizd, so the Shahanshah commanded his armies to march on her remaining territories.
Among all candidates vying for the title of Emperor, Hormizd recognised Aurelian as the lawful one. It was therefore decided that war would be waged upon Aurelian until he succumbed.
The time had come for the next step in the war against Rome. Hormizd personally selected several Roman settlements and unleashed his armies upon them.

Hormizd was well versed in history. He knew well the story of Emperor Trajan who conquered the Dacians and took their capital, Zarmizegetusa. Sassanid troops laid waste to Zarmizegetusa to avenge the honour of the defeated Dacians.
The Immortals were the Shahanshah's personal guard - the well-honed edge that struck with deadly precision in his name. It is said that they were never more feared than during Hormizd's reign.
Dealing with the remnants of Rome was merely an annoyance for the almighty Shahanshah. Yet it had to be done, if only for the pleasure of seeing Aurelian bound in chains before the Sassanid throne.
At the zenith of his rule, Hormizd proclaimed his domain an Empire of East and West. It is beyond doubt that his predecessors would have been proud of his many accomplishments.

Having It All

The south is proud and ambitious; Etruscans and Romans, Italians and Greeks all scramble there, vying for superiority. We have the wisdom to step in and restore order, and the common sense to remain to see it is kept.

With the growth of our domains, the responsibilities and glory of our leaders have risen in tandem. To match them, we must improve our understanding of construction techniques, ensuring we our buildings achieve a new level of majesty. The world, in return, will be more agreeable...

Brennus' greatness is unchallenged. His conduct, on the other hand, invites criticism: his inclination to sell his sword to the highest bidder makes him an unreliable ally; his passion for sacking cities has made him a hated brute. Now, no one would cry at his demise!

We control a vast domain, which allows us to shape the world according to our choices. A stronghold in Corsica will ensure that the sea, just as the land, becomes a secure border against attack from without.
To ensure the success in their struggle against the Romans in Britannia, the Caledonii summoned many warriors to their armies. Many more answered the call than the chiefs expected.
In the wake of the Caledonii uprising, more and more people spoke of the druids. From secluded forests and mountain hideouts, figures clad in white descended, bearing the knowledge of ages past.
The Caledonii had heard stories of the Germanic barbarians and found their reputed savagery repulsive. An expedition against them was sent to teach them to fear the Caledonii name.
Living for so long close to the Romans taught some Caledonii chiefs that civilisation had many advantages. These same chiefs supported friendship with the different factions of Roman origin.
A market is a place where people could gather and exchange goods and services. In these places, concord is achieved and everyone grows wealthier.
Meanwhile, the Caledonii sent an envoy to Emperor Aurelian, respectfully explaining their desire to share their amassed wealth with the people of Rome.
As the war continued, loot from the coffers of vanquished cities was distributed evenly among the warriors to ensure their willingness to fight on.
The king of the Caledonii's special guard comprised battle-hardened veterans, who had made a solemn vow to their lord... a vow that only death could sunder.
A majestic sacred grove was selected by the druidic high council. There, amid the whispering trees, decisions were made that would shape the destiny of the world.

Diplomacy is a useful tool for achieving political goals. Its virility, however, depends on the strength of our tribe. However, to be successful during the talks we must first be effective with our boots - it is wise to control the territories in our immediate vicinity.
The rest of northern Italy lies before us, fertile and with favourable terrain. Gaining control over it promises to be highly beneficial; with our skills and wisdom, it also seems easily achievable.
The contribution of each member of the tribe was deemed important; the Caledonii knew that the mighty ocean is but a collection of water drops.

The last Legions in Britannia could hardly believe the cold reality they faced as the Caledonii gradually overcame their resistance. Shame filled their hearts, but victory was destined to elude their grasp.

Once their hold over Britannia was complete, the Caledonii turned their gaze towards Gallic Rome. As they could not yet hope to overcome Emperor Tetricus, they opted to establish trade relations instead.
The constant transport of warriors from Britannia to the mainland demanded a fleet of appropriate size. This same fleet, if sufficiently sturdy, could ferry the Caledonii wherever they wished to go.
The war chiefs knew that choosing the next target for conquest was an art in its own right. Correctly chosen, the threatened state would succumb peacefully to Caledonii rule.
Fighting a Roman force was something the Caledonii knew how to do. The first requirement was having an army of suitably impressive size to counter their numbers.
Certain warriors who distinguished themselves in many battles were given noble steeds to ride upon. In this way, a fierce yet disciplined cavalry force was born.
The druids had returned and their influence was slowly growing. As more people joined their ranks, the tenets of educated and honourable life spread through Caledonii lands.
Emperor Tetricus defied the Caledonii with strength and guile. Still, his Legions could not prevail and soon the dream of an independent Gallic Rome was but a memory.

Securing the mountain ranges to the east should protect us from unpleasant surprises, as some of the local tribes are traditionally inclined to show up unannounced and cause damage. Simultaneously, it is strategically prudent to acquire access to the sea.

Toutatis is both a strong ally and a fearsome adversary. We rely on his good graces to maintain our daily lives and secure us from attack. Honouring him, through sacred buildings and religious structures, may yet ensure his continued divine protection.

Our hills are blessed with an abundance of the required ore and our craftsmen possess the ancient knowledge for transforming it into bronze ingots. Furthermore, they have the skills to fashion all sorts of useful objects from this highly-versatile, malleable material. They must always have access to the necessary facilities.

The backbone of our army are its strong and powerful longswords. If we are to have a lasting legacy, we must ensure that we field an unbeatable force. The recruitment of half a dozen well-trained units is a reasonable first step towards achieving this.

Salt is a precious resource. We know of many quarrels that have escalated into battles and all triggered by it. We also know of markets where it can be easily sold for profit. With our workshops, we can ensure a steady production and a lucrative stream of resultant wealth.

Our territories grow, and along with them, the number of people under our control. Our adversaries grow desperate and more aggressive. To maintain and solidify our position, we must ensure the battlefield strength of our infantry is second to none.
A great leader is measured by their legacy. This High Hall of Kings will is a worthy legacy for our leaders, past, current and future!
The only thing stronger than well-trained, experienced army is a much larger, more experienced and better-trained force.
Brennus is a leader of mythic proportions. Stories of his achievements, strength and bravery are both a great source of knowledge and provide inspiration to younger members of the Senones tribe.
The moves of a master warrior are flawless and elegant. To become one requires endless practice, but starts with the fundamentals of the art, such as perfecting poise and balance.

Even though we are self-sufficient when it comes to food, clothes and shelter, there are some items we cannot produce alone, and for them we rely on trade. Establishing mercantile partnerships requires a good reputation and trust between the parties, which is not always easy to achieve.

It is known that Dionysius relies on mercenaries to execute many of his political manoeuvres. He is also renowned for his fair and generous treatment of his allies. We have no conflicting interests with the tyrant; maybe, following due discussion, we can find some common ground between us.

The Etruscans used to be a formidable presence in Italy, with a colourful culture of their own. However, it wasn't sufficient to keep them relevant in the present day - there is no longer room to accommodate the scattered remnants of a vanishing people.
Brennus is a fearsome foe and an even more horrifying victor; maybe he will spare the lives of his enemies, maybe he won't. His judgement, however, will be final.
Success rests on the acquisition of sufficient resources and their wise and prudent use. Securing essential resources is always a prudent measure, one that promises stability and peace for all.

As Tetricus' power grew, he instituted a body of elite soldiers to serve as his personal guard. Deadly in their prowess and unswerving in their loyalty, these soldiers would readily give their lives to protect the Emperor.

Although the province of Raetia and Noricum was almost completely under Gallic control, Tetricus desired the fortified city of Noreia; such a fortified position would give him easy access to the provinces of Illyricum and Cisalpina.

The island province of Corsica et Sardinia held great naval importance, which Tetricus easily recognised; control over the isles would facilitate further expansion into Africa as well as protection of nearby trade routes.

The campaigns against the Germanic tribes did not end with control over the Rhenus. In order to secure the safety of Gallic lands, Tetricus intended to push the entire border further east across Magna Germania.
Abandoned Legionary camps dotted the countryside. Each was in a suitable defensive position; Tetricus set out to rebuild them in order to strengthen Gallic Rome's defences.
Roman Numidia was a rich province to the west of Carthage. The African conquest could not be considered truly completed until Tetricus extended his rule over these lands.
Tetricus' ambitions were not limited to Roman lands. He also needed to exact vengeance upon the Sassanids for the Valerian's cruel death at their hands. The score would be settled in ruin and fire...
Tetricus spent a great deal of coin promoting Roman rule throughout the lands under his control. The people in his newly-conquered regions were quick to align themselves with the Romans.
The Sassanids had conquered Armenia, but as their power diminished, Tetricus set out to bring Roman rule to the ancient kingdom.

As formidable as Roman strength undoubtedly was, Tetricus had to ensure that no external threat was too big for the Legions to tackle. This is why he expanded his armed forces to a degree never before seen.

Gallic Rome's auxiliaries consisted of experienced fighters who had fought both for Rome and occasionally for the Germanic war chiefs. These men formed the backbone of Tetricus' formidable fighting forces.
As the Germanic tribes grew bolder, Tetricus had to take up the initiative against them. This involved crossing the Rhenus and establishing firm Roman rule on the other shore.
Holding the city of Rome seemed insufficient. All accomplices of the pretender Quintillus had to be dealt with if peace was to be established in Latium, Italia and Sicily.

Tetricus had long dreamt of completing the conquest of Britannia, as envisioned by the great Emperor Septimius Severus. Septimius had been stopped by the Caledonii and their devious ways, yet his successor would not repeat old mistakes.
Emperor Aurelian still had a number of allies on the south coast of Pontus Euxinus. Removing any of these would deal a significant blow to his ability to fight.
Aurelian was a brave man and a worthy foe, but he was also stubborn and single-minded. He would never accept Tetricus as legal Emperor, so there was only one sure way to get rid of him…
As long as Queen Zenobia independently ruled, Emperor Tetricus would always be threatened by her treacherous nature. She had to be subdued, one way or another…
The Gothi had been a thorn in Rome's side for far too long. Tetricus and his Legions marched against them to put an end to this affront to Rome's existence once and for all.

Tetricus initiated numerous reforms that aimed to restore Roman government to its ancient, purely Republican form. Of course, he himself was to lead Rome as 'Consul in Perpetuo', but that was understandable.

The Mistress of Egypt
Rome: the city of wealth and prosperity; the city that could have ruled the world. For Kush, defeating the Romans was just another in a long line of victories, itself a symbol of the kingdom's might.
The path to true greatness is long and hard; just one mis-step could lead to destruction, but there are some who walk it proudly and without fear. Behold Kush, the true masters of the world!
As the economy flourished and Kushite kingdom grew, it was inevitable that the ancient land of Egypt would have to come under their control.
Over time, the kingdom of Kush expanded much further, subjugating its neighbours beneath an iron fist.
The kingdom of Kush played an important role in the trade of the region, which helped the Kushites achieve considerable wealth and prosperity.
To see beyond the horizon is always beneficial; to know of your rivals' movements is always wise. The good spy is worth a hundred soldiers.

The customs governing the consumption and storage of food are indicative of a society's level of sophistication. We strive to use only the very best the world has to offer, so naturally we buy Etruscan.
We appreciate the benefits of trade. Establishing mercantile partnerships requires a good reputation and trust between the parties, which isn't easy to achieve.

This 'republic' of theirs seems to unite them with a feeling of misplaced superiority. They are relentless and stubborn, but know how to fight, so we must not underestimate them - Rome will continue to wreak havoc in central Italy until we take care of our own interests!

Brennus and his gang of foul barbarians recently arrived in Italy, raiding villages and sacking cities as they went. Such acts are not the way to make friends. It is, though, a sure path for creating foes. Not a sensible course of action, as some foes hold grudges forever...

The horses of Venetia are the backbone of our society, the strength of our army and the basis of transportation and agricultural work. It is imperative that we know everything about breeding and keeping these fine animals.
Success rests on the acquisition of sufficient resources and their wise and prudent use. Securing essential resources is always a prudent measure, one that promises stability and peace for all.
Following their dreams of conquest, the Kushites spread out in both eastward and westward directions, reaching out into the corners of the known world.
The vast lands of Kush required even greater armies to keep the peace and protect their borders, but soon this newly-acquired might would echo through history.
With victory after victory increasing their confidence, even the sea's many perils could not halt Kush's relentless progress.

We are blessed with fine, vast pastures capable of supporting large herds of cattle. They provide a generous source of wealth, food and clothes for our tribe. Constructing more cattle pens will help us accommodate larger numbers of animals.
The bardic tradition sings of our kin's origins and history - it sings of our warriors' heroic deeds and praises the beauty of our women. The bards provide the musical accompaniment to our lives.

The backbone of our army are its strong and powerful heavy cavalry. If we are to have a lasting legacy, we must ensure that we field an unbeatable force. The recruitment of half a dozen well-trained units is a reasonable first step towards achieving this.

Salt is a precious resource. We know of many quarrels that have escalated into battles and all triggered by it. We also know of markets where it can be easily sold for profit. With our workshops, we can ensure a steady production and a lucrative stream of resultant wealth.

As our territories expand, so too does the number of people living under our yoke. As we grow, so do our adversaries grow more desperate and more aggressive. To maintain and solidify our position, we must ensure the mobility of our armies is second to none.
A great leader is measured by their legacy. This High Hall of Kings will is a worthy legacy for our leaders, past, current and future!
The only thing stronger than well-trained, experienced army is a much larger, more experienced and better-trained force.
The time had come for Kush to ascend to its rightful position as one of the ancient world's greatest powers. The kingdom's rulers were more than capable of achieving such a feat.

The forests of Insubria are generous, supplying us with food, wood and clothing. We have to profess our gratitude and respect to the gods - it is due to their blessings that we enjoy this abundance of game, fruits, and timber.

To sack a city requires efficiency, discipline and courage, and a successful sacking can be highly profitable. We not only possess the necessary talents but can also find a good use for the spoils. Do we really need to make further arguments\? Improving our sacking skills can only be to our benefit.

Even though we are self-sufficient when it comes to food, clothes and shelter, there are some items we cannot produce alone, and for them we rely on trade. Establishing mercantile partnerships requires a good reputation and trust between the parties, which is not always easy to achieve.

The Iolei are an unpretentious people originating from the island of Sardinia. They are great archers and proficient defenders. Securing an alliance with them will help to secure our coasts. The region's naval powers would then focus on the Iolei, thereby allowing us to pursue our own agenda.

The Etruscans used to be a formidable presence in Italy, with a colourful culture of their own. However, it wasn't sufficient to keep them relevant in the present day - there is no longer room to accommodate the scattered remnants of a vanishing people.

A brotherhood of warriors, facing peril or glory; in the name of Insubria, our young, brave riders live and die according to the ancient tradition of Trimarcisia. Our enemies, on the other hand, often succumb in the face of such devotion!
Success rests on the acquisition of sufficient resources and their wise and prudent use. Securing essential resources is always a prudent measure, one that promises stability and peace for all.

Our lands are fertile; we rely on them for the majority of our food. As our farming expertise grows, production is starting to diversify. A larger market will help significantly, improving distribution of the produce.

Water is fundamental for life, and as such should be revered as holy. Water deities should always be honoured and worshipped, for their good graces are the only insurance we have that we will continue to enjoy an abundance of spring water, and all the benefits it provides.

The backbone of our army are its strong and powerful longswords. If we are to have a lasting legacy, we must ensure that we field an unbeatable force. The recruitment of half a dozen well-trained units is a reasonable first step towards achieving this.

The horns of Insubria are famous across Italy - they instil fear in the very hearts of their enemies, and awaken pride and passion during rituals and celebrations. Horns are also a valuable trade good. Naturally, our craftsmen would be pleased with larger workshops in which to work.

Our territories grow, and along with them, the number of people under our control. Our adversaries grow desperate and more aggressive. To maintain and solidify our position, we must ensure the battlefield strength of our infantry is second to none.
A great leader is measured by their legacy. This High Hall of Kings will is a worthy legacy for our leaders, past, current and future!
The only thing stronger than well-trained, experienced army is a much larger, more experienced and better-trained force.
With the east secure and under control, it was time for the Nabateans to turn their attention to the west, and march into the very heart of Alexander's once mighty empire.
With many provinces under their control, there was no shortage of men to fight Nabataea's wars, and it soon raised one of the largest standing armies in the world at that time.
Their many victories on the battlefield invigorated the Nabataean people, and it was not long before they desired further conquest.
Nabataea was destined to become one of the greatest kingdoms of ancient times, with vast lands under its rule and borders spanning many hundreds of miles.
After its recent conquests, Nabataea needed to increase the number of armies it fielded to ensure the safety of its people.
With its fearless desert warriors, Nabataea continued to expand northwards, putting the ancient cities of the Great Sea under its mighty yoke.

Nabataea was strategically well-positioned between two of the larger kingdoms ruled by Alexander's Successors, Ptolemaic Egypt and the Seleucid Empire, which made it hard for it to expand the kingdom's borders.
As their power eclipsed all others, the Nabataeans soon began to expand in all directions, bringing with them the wealth and prosperity of their glorious kingdom.
Through hardships and struggles, Nabataea rose to greatness to become one of the largest kingdoms of all time, scoring its name forever into the annals of history.
The Sabaean people soon realised that if they wanted to flourish and prosper, they had to control the surrounding small kingdoms.
The defence of Ma'rib was heavily dependant on mercenaries paid for by Saba's wealthy nobles.
The Great Dam of Ma'rib had long provided sustenance for the people of Saba, but as borders expanded, so did the dam.
Moving goods from one place to another often involved navigating many dangers, but Saba established a vast network of roadside inns called 'caravanserais', to offer safe haven for travellers.
A combination of Saba's expansion through conquest and the trade routes they established helped the Sabaean economy to flourish.
The province of Aethiopia played an important strategic role in securing all trade routes heading to and from southern Africa, so Saba needed to control it in order to flourish further.
From the improvements made to the Great Dam, to the construction of many important temples, the people of Saba were considered master engineers.
The city of Carthago was prosperous and wealthy; it would've made a great addition to Saba's territorial jewellery box.
Even though Saba had become one of the largest kingdoms in the east, a trade agreement with Rome was still a wise move - for what Rome envied, she tended to conquer.
With its strategic location in Arabia Felix, Saba soon established many trade routes to both the east and west.
Spices were a much sought after commodity; the Sabaeans knew how to turn that demand to their advantage.
To further expand and improve its trade routes, Saba needed ports, not only on the Arabian Peninsula, but on the Great Sea as well.
Their fortuitous access to exotic goods helped Saba acquire many trade partners all over the known world.
There were always new frontiers and kingdoms to trade with; the Sabaean people would not miss a single opportunity in their dogged pursuit of wealth.
With many other kingdoms contesting the Great Sea, Saba needed to build great fleets in order to establish its dominance over the waves.
Different lands breed different classes of warrior; Saba gradually united them all to fight for wealth and glory.
The economy of Saba was a grand machine with numerous moving parts all serving a single purpose: making the kingdom enviably rich.
Goods from every corner of the world were moved through Saba every day; the most luxurious goods that money can buy.
A young Marcomanni warrior lusted for riches above all else. Impatient to rush into Roman lands, some of them banded together and descended upon a settlement with plunder in mind.

Neighbouring tribes recognised the growing power of the Marcomanni and decided they desired to be a part of their glory. The Marcomanni readily welcomed the additional warriors that joined their forces.
During their assault of Pannonia, the Marcomanni thoroughly plundered the countryside. With the Legions unable to stop the invaders, the local folk left their homes in search of safety.
The Marcomanni had scored victory after victory. With their might swiftly increasing, it became necessary to increase the number of warriors they could field.

The Marcomanni not only fielded fierce troops, they also showed an unsurpassed level of tactical knowledge. When facing them in battle, the Roman Legions were often surprised to find themselves facing tactics of their own design.
For years, the Marcomanni had been landlocked in the forests of Hercynia. Now the time had come for them to sail the rich waters of the Mare Internum for glory and yet more plunder.
The strongest and most influential of the Marcomanni warriors were enlisted in the Noble Guard - heavily armoured troops that protected the king at all times.

The queen of Palmyra had heard of the Marcomanni and their numerous exploits against the Roman Emperors. Undoubtedly, she would have willingly sent her finest merchants to Marcomannic lands in the spirit of mercantilism.
Marcomanni noblemen wanted a palace of singular magnificence, where they could convene and discuss the matters of the day before the king himself.
Although at one point the Marcomanni offered their friendship to Tetricus, they were eager to fight him when they became confident in their own strength.
The Marcomanni had little fancy for waging war in distant, sun-scorched lands. However they were not opposed to profitable trade with the people who lived there.
The Quadi tribe often sent warriors to help the Marcomanni when needed, and expected aid in return. With proper handling, they could've become a stout and loyal ally.
While the Marcomanni sought the downfall of Emperor Aurelian for reasons of their own, they extended a hand of friendship to Tetricus of Gallic Rome.
The walled city of Noreia had stood watch over Alpine passes for many years. With its capture, the Marcomanni gained control over the winding mountain roads nearby.

The land the Romans called 'Magna Germania' was split between various Germanic tribes. The Marcomanni moved to unite them by conquest and negotiation, becoming masters of Magna Germania in the process.
Control of the Alpine mountain passes gave the Marcomanni easy access to the soft underbelly of Cisalpina. They struck at Mediolanum and utterly sacked the great city.
Various Germanic chieftains claimed common ancestry with the Marcomanni in order to easily join the budding barbarian empire.
Before the conquest of Rome was complete, the Marcomanni gave into their greed and robbed the noble citizens of their precious possessions.
The province of Numidia was a semi-independent state that proved to be a nuisance as it was still loyal to Rome. Therefore, the Marcomanni decided to wipe it out.
The Marcomanni, almost drunk with power, turned against all their might against Gallic Rome. Proud Tetricus attempted to mount a defence, though he was well aware that, ultimately, he would fail.

The defenders of Rome fought bravely - the bravery of desperation. Yet, the Gothi prevailed and their hordes rushed onto the streets of the Eternal City. The great sacking lasted for days and when it was complete, only crows inhabited empty buildings.

The Gothi rampaged across the remains of the Roman Empire. City after city fell beneath their heels. Never before had the world seen such great terror. The glory of the Roman Empire was forever ruined.

The wise Gothic reiks, Cannabaudes, led his warriors straight for the Roman city of Zarmizegetusa. In order to establish firm control over Dacia, the Gothi had to deal with the Roxolani, a warlike steppe tribe. Perhaps they would be willing to enter an alliance\?

Then the Gothi marched south along the west coast of Pontus Euxinus. They plundered the countryside with their usual vigour; conquest was their goal, however, and soon every coastal town fell to their blades.
The Gothi poured into Roman lands and put them to the torch. Woe upon the Roman people! Woe upon their Emperor! The barbarian hordes were unstoppable in their bloodlust.
The cities of Thessalonika and Athens were the next to fall before the Gothic onslaught. The locals were said to have abandoned their homes as soon as they heard that the Gothi were approaching.
Cannabaudes then ordered the Gothi to advance into the steppe territories to the north and east of Pontus Euxinus. No longer would they suffer the raids of nomadic horsemen.
The Gothi proceeded to attack all Roman territories to the south of Pontus Euxinus, reaching as far Antioch. Never before had a Gothic reiks reigned over lands of such intense heat.

The Gothi gathered their armies for a massive western invasion. Their goal was to control the area around the Alps, which in turn would open their way to the south... where Rome would be at their mercy.
As large as the Alani kingdom was, there were still lands to conquer and people to subjugate. What were the limits of their might\? It seemed that there were none…
Satisfied with their massive eastern conquest, the Alani turned to the west. Their forces rode along the Danuvius and subdued the lands on both sides of the great river.
With the Roman Empire split into warring factions, its once glorious cities were easy prey to marauding parties. The Alani were swift to exploit the situation.
The agricultural land to the south was not hospitable enough for the Alani and their horses. Yet as long as cities fell before them, they did not intend to stop their advance.

The Alani then rode to the east, across the plains that sprawled beyond the Caspian Sea. The people there lived a semi-nomadic life and were independent and unruly. However, their fall was inevitable and imminent.

Many great people fell before the Alani. Some of them fought to the end but others sued for peace at the first possible opportunity, often in exchange for servitude. Either way, the Alani were pleased.
The Alani were accustomed to a life of herding and raiding, but their power gradually grew until they came to control Scythia in its entirety.
Sarmatia spread along the north coast of Pontus Euxinus all the way to the River Danuvius. It was the next target of the Alani on their quest for total dominance of the plains.
The proud kingdom of Bosporou had withstood hundreds of nomadic raids, as in most cases the attackers came to steal and then run away again. However, the Alani had come to conquer and subdue.

Everything in life is predestined, as described in our religious texts. We consult Libri Rituales to learn where and how to build. The book also defines our rituals, tells of Etruscan longevity and foretells our end.

We taught them everything, even gave them several of their kings - we know them better than they know themselves. Manipulating the Romans is a simple task, and one that serves our long-term interests.

Tarchuna is a significant trade hub, where a variety of goods are traded, bartered and exchanged. Establishing partnerships requires a good reputation and trust between parties, which is not an easy thing to achieve.

Archytas is an enlightened leader of a prosperous city, highly revered among his people as both a famous thinker and an inspired inventor. The interests of our cities do not converge, however, so we have nothing to naturally fight over. There is a lot to be gained by both parties if we join together in common cause.

Brennus and his gang of foul barbarians recently arrived in Italy, raiding villages and sacking cities as they went. Such acts are not the way to make friends. It is, though, a sure path for creating foes. Not a sensible course of action, as some foes hold grudges forever...

Etruscan cities cherish their independence and the diversity of their culture. The mutual respect between us allows us to compete amongst ourselves and stick together when dealing with outsiders. When there are cardinal matters to discuss, our elders come together at the Shrine of Voltumnae.
Success rests on the acquisition of sufficient resources and their wise and prudent use. Securing essential resources is always a prudent measure, one that promises stability and peace for all.
A sophisticated society requires clever organisation and a structure that endures. Every statesman appreciates a smoothly working administration; the challenge is to improve and perfect its function.

Equilibrium is achieved when all groups in a society are content with their status and share of the wealth. Sometimes, the richest among us are the most unhappy, but who can blame them for wanting a home suitable for people of status\?

Our army's backbone is its strong and powerful hoplites. If we are to have a lasting legacy, we must ensure that our forces are unbeatable. The recruitment of half a dozen well-trained units is a reasonable first step towards achieving this.

We are close acquaintances of the god Nethuns. The lion's share of our food comes from the sea, our generous patron and trusted friend. To maintain our growth, we must harvest more and construct larger ports.

As our territories expand, so too does the number of people living under our yoke. As we grow, so do our adversaries grow more desperate and more aggressive. To maintain and solidify our position, we must ensure the battlefield strength of our infantry is second to none.

Tinia is both a strong ally and a fearsome adversary. We rely on his good graces to maintain security in our daily lives. Honouring him, through sacred buildings and structures, is one of the many ways to ensure His divine protection.
The only thing stronger than well-trained, experienced army is a much larger, more experienced and better-trained force.

When knowledge is acquired it shall be written down, and so preserved. This is the way all civilised people learn and pass this learning on to the younger generation.
Athletics allow man to prove his worth before the gods. We, the Greeks, introduced and maintain the tradition of the Olympic Games, spending time and money training our youth for sporting victory.

Artillery is our army's secret weapon. If we are to have a lasting legacy, we must ensure our forces are unbeatable. The recruitment of half a dozen well-trained ballista units is a reasonable initial step towards achieving this end.

Syracuse is in love with Athena; how could it be otherwise\? She is the patron of the greatest intelligence, wisdom and military strategy in man. We honour Athena with rituals at elaborately-constructed temples dedicated to the goddess.

As our territories expand, so too does the number of people living under our yoke. As we grow, so do our adversaries grow more desperate and more aggressive. To maintain and solidify our position, we must ensure the devastating power of our artillery on the battlefield.

We are people of the sea and much of our strength is derived from it. Our ports are enormously powerful tools for control of Italy and the seas surrounding it. Our ambitions require greater fleets, more personnel to man them, and larger ports.
The only thing stronger than well-trained, experienced army is a much larger, more experienced and better-trained force.
Every successful endeavour of significant proportions is down to knowledge. We are the Greeks and the world is our canvas; it is greatly improved by our efforts!

Our fleets allow us to control the waves far and wide; the element of surprise giving us a huge advantage when launching attacks on coastal settlements. To deal with such situations, we also train our sailors to fight like regular infantry.

Syracuse is a trade centre of significant proportions, producing a variety of quality goods for which we are rightly famous. Establishing mercantile partnerships requires a good reputation and trust between parties, which isn't easy to achieve.

Dionysius has a way of dealing with barbarians - they seem to trust and respect him, and he always finds ways to best use their combat abilities. Brennus is the leaders of the Senones; Dionysius believes Syracuse and the Senones can be partners…
There was a time when we could live together in harmony. This time has passed; Taras' inability to accept their rightful place - as our inferior cousins - will lead only to their doom!

Dionysius is a leader of great character and ability; he doesn't shy away from contact with the common people and is in touch with the hopes and fears of his people. He has dedicated his life to the city, and is highly revered for it.
Success rests on the acquisition of sufficient resources and their wise and prudent use. Securing essential resources is always a prudent measure, one that promises stability and peace for all.
