By that time, Quintillus, brother to the late Claudius Gothicus, held the power in Rome. Aurelian did not waste a single day but quickly headed west to meet the leader of the pretenders.
With the city of Rome in his hands, Aurelian expanded his influence further. He knew well that his struggle was far from over; in fact, it had only just begun.
The Emperor recognised that wars against Zenobia and Tetricus would impose a great strain on the Imperial treasury. This is why he needed to establish a steady flow of gold into his coffers.

The city of Antioch on Mare Internum's eastern shore was a gateway to the territories under Zenobia's control. Once it fell, Aurelian's Legions marched straight towards Palmyra almost without resistance.
Aurelian marched for Palmyra with the blessing of Sol Invictus. At the time, it was unclear whether he intended to spare the desert gem or bury it in the sands.

Palmyra had fallen and Aurelian turned his gaze to the west. He needed to control the Alps, the south coast of Gaul and Hispania simultaneously if he was to swiftly succeed in the war against Gallic Rome.
The assault against Gallic Rome was under way. Aurelian's mighty Legions struck north at the heart of the traitors, cutting a path of bloody destruction through their lands.
The only proper way for Aurelian to express his gratitude to Sol Invictus was to construct a temple that matched the deity in splendour and greatness.
Aurelian's advance to the east was met with stiff resistance. Still, with the united Roman Empire behind him, the Emperor was unstoppable.
Zeal:
There were other small kingdoms bordering Kush, but they were overshadowed by its prosperity and growing might.
As the kingdom of Kush grew in size and stature, it needed to recruit ever-increasing numbers of warriors to keep its borders safe.
With the Nile secure and the kingdom prospering, the ever-avaricious eyes of the Kushites turned eastwards.
Strength at sea was important for Kush to secure established trade routes and the safety of its own borders.
Riches were not as much of a rarity in the desert as some might think; the people of Kush were a living testament to that.
Even the once-great city of Carthago was unable to withstand the overwhelming might of Kush's military forces.
Kush would leave its mark in history, not just through military victory and conquest, but via its burgeoning cultural and spiritual influence also.
There is no place in the world for two great kingdoms. Some prosper while others crumble and fall to dust; it is the natural order of things.
Even the Great Sea looked tiny to mighty Kush, whose empire now extended all around its coasts.
Sending slaves into battle was not something frowned upon in the ancient world; the Kushite people were renowned slavers and the poor unfortunates they controlled were totally expendable.
Once, mighty Egypt was a force to be reckoned with, but times have changed and now the Ptolemaic Dynasty - usurpers to this ancient land - must be brought to an end.
As the Kushite kingdom grew, potential trade partners were discovered, along with new lands, ripe for conquest and absorption.
The hardy, enterprising people of Kush were born in the desert sands, and prosper there.
Eventually, Kush discovered that all roads did indeed lead to Rome. As the two powers clashed over trade rights, war inevitably followed.
Kush employed deadly, exotic beasts to swell their battle ranks, which struck fear into the hearts of their unfortunate opponents.
As time wore on, land after land was united under Kush's rule, bringing them the greatness of which their ancestors could only dream.
Military victories were not the only thing that brought Kush to greatness. The riches of the world now fuelled its economy, making it one of the wealthiest kingdoms in existence.
Kush's symbol, the lion-headed god, soon became known all across the world; the wise feared his disciples, as war and destruction followed wherever they went.

Sheep and goats are the animals most suited to our native mountains. We rely on them for food, milk, clothes, even weapons. Herding grounds allow us to breed healthy animals in larger numbers.

Our hills are blessed with an abundance of the required ore and our craftsmen possess the ancient knowledge for transforming it into bronze ingots. Furthermore, they have the skills to fashion all sorts of useful objects from this highly-versatile, malleable material. They must always have access to the necessary facilities.

The backbone of our army are its strong and powerful spearmen. If we are to have a lasting legacy, we must ensure that we field an unbeatable force. The recruitment of half a dozen well-trained units is a reasonable first step towards achieving this.

One way of acquiring wealth is to sell one’s own produce; another is to provide a common space where others can sell the fruits of their labour. The larger the space, the more profitable the arrangement.

As our territories expand, so too does the number of people living under our yoke. As we grow, so do our adversaries grow more desperate and more aggressive. To maintain and solidify our position, we must ensure the battlefield strength of our infantry is second to none.
Our present glory is built on the blood of heroes and the many sacrifices made by the entire Samnite people. We shall keep their memory alive, just as their deeds allow us to exist.
The only thing stronger than well-trained, experienced army is a much larger, more experienced and better-trained force.
When the times require it, we turn to the divine and offer our most precious possessions: our children. Twenty years later, they will leave the tribe in search of a new home.
There is a natural order to the world. The Samnite man must protect his homeland, his slave's job is to tend the fields, look after our herds and to assist us in our daily activities.

Even though we are self-sufficient when it comes to food, clothes and shelter, there are some items we cannot produce alone, and for them we rely on trade. Establishing mercantile partnerships requires a good reputation and trust between the parties, which is not always easy to achieve.

The Iolei are an unpretentious people originating from the island of Sardinia. They are great archers and proficient defenders. Securing an alliance with them will help to secure our coasts. The region's naval powers would then focus on the Iolei, thereby allowing us to pursue our own agenda.

At first, they showed some potential. Then, they bet their future on their great 'republic' - a civilised society like no other. However, the spark that brought Rome into existence will never turn into a raging, uncontrollable fire.
The moves of a master warrior are flawless and elegant. To become one requires endless practice, but starts with the fundamentals of the art, such as perfecting poise and balance.
Success rests on the acquisition of sufficient resources and their wise and prudent use. Securing essential resources is always a prudent measure, one that promises stability and peace for all.
